headline.main: DEPARTURE OF SENATOR SEWARD FOR EUROPE.; Proceedings of the Republican Committees--Senator Seward's Reception and Speech at the Residence of Isaac Bell, Jr.

docs.lead_paragraph: The two Republican Central Committees met last evening, at their Rooms, No. 018 Broadway, having been specially called together for the purpose of tendering an escort to Senator SXWARD, who us about to embank for Europe. Judge PEABODY presided. A Committes of five from each Central Committes was appointed to make the necessary arrangements,

docs.lead_paragraph: COMMEMORATIVE DISCOURSE BY THE REV. V. DANCE, OF HOBOKEN. The Rev. V. Bauce, Rector of St. Paul's Church, in Hoboken, last Sunday delivered a discourse commemorative of the late Right Rev. Bishop DOAUE. His text was taken from Exodus, 330 chapter and 14th verse:

headline.main: EUROPE.; ADVICES THREE DAYS LATER. Arrival of the Niagara at Halifax. The Last Efforts for Peace Exhausted. The English Propositions Rejected by Austria. Austrian Ultimatum Addressed to Sardinia. DECLARATION OF WAR IMMINENT. French and Austrian Troops Advancing Towards Piedmont. A COLLISION INEVITABLE. Depressing Effect of the News upon the Paris Bourse. Cotton at a Decline--Breadstuffs Dull--Consols 94 1-2. [By the American Telegraph Company's Lines--Offices No. 21 Wall-street.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The R. M. steamship Niagara, Capt. MILLAR, from Liverpool at 1 o'clock on the afternoon of April 23, arrived at Halifax at about 10 o'clock last night, but, for reasons which will at a future time be explained, the Agent of the Associated Press was Compelled to sent the intelligence thence to this place by horse-express.

docs.snippet: A projected elopement from Havre to New-York was recently nipped in the bud. A letter from Havre says: On Saturday a lady and two gentlemen alighted at a hotel, and took tickets for their passage to New-York on board the Mercury. On the same day,...
docs.lead_paragraph: A projected elopement from Havre to New-York was recently nipped in the bud. A letter from Havre says: On Saturday a lady and two gentlemen alighted at a hotel, and took tickets for their passage to New-York on board the Mercury. On the same day, while the party were preparing to visit the town, a telegraphic dispatch arrived from Amounts.

headline.main: Organization of the Brooklyn Common Council.; Appointment of Clerks and other Officials. MAYOR POWELL'S MESSAGE.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first meeting of the Common Council of Brooklyn met at the City Hall last evening, and all the members were present. The first business done was the election of the following officers, all of whom are Democrats. President of the Board--Martin Kalbrietsch.

headline.main: NEWS BY TELEGRAPH.; THE CALIFORNIA MAIL CONTRACT--THE UTAH TROUBLES--SWINDLING IN THE WAR DEPARTMENT--MOVEMENTS OF MINISTER McLANE, &C. From Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nothing is yet known as to the bids for the Pacific mail service, nor will there be any communication on the subject by the Post-office Department until the decision is made. It is reported but the delay in awarding the contract is owing to difference in the Nicaragua Canal Company.

headline.main: The Health Bill at Albany -- Note from Gen. Wetmore.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is not my intention to enter into a newspaper controversy with Mr. SPENOER, or any other person, in regard to the circumstances which attended the loss of the New-York Health Bill in the Assembly, on the 19th of April last. The incidents of that memorable occurrence were open to the observation of more than a hundred persons, and I have yet to learn from satisfactory

docs.lead_paragraph: Board of Alderman. ANOTHER NOMINATION FOR CITY INSPECTOR, RETURNED TO THE MAYOR--PREPARATIONS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY--REPAIRING BROADWAY--ADDITIONAL CLERKS FOR THE COMPTROLLER. headline.main: The Health Bill at Albany--Letter from the Hon. Charles S. Spencer.

docs.lead_paragraph: FIRST MAKING OF THE NEW BOARD OF ALDERMAN--NO QUORUM-The first meeting of the new Board of Aldermen was called for 5 o'clock least evening. Soon after that hour Mayor POWELL took the Chair and called the Board to order. The roll was called, when the following Aldermen answered to their names: Cashon, Jenkins, Taylor, Van Brunt,
